abstractText: We propose commuting set of matrix-valued difference operators in terms of the elliptic BaxterBelavin R-matrix in the fundamental representation of GLM . In the scalar case M = 1 these operators are the elliptic Macdonald-Ruijsenaars operators, while in the general case they can be viewed as anisotropic versions of the quantum spin Ruijsenaars Hamiltonians. We show that commutativity of the operators for any M is equivalent to a set of R-matrix identities. The proof of identities is based on the properties of elliptic R-matrix including the quantum and the associative Yang-Baxter equations. As an application of our results, we introduce elliptic generalization of q-deformed Haldane-Shastry model.

1 Introduction

The elliptic Macdonald-Ruijsenaars operators were introduced in [42] generalizing the (trigonometric) Macdonald operators [34]. These operators can be viewed as a set of commuting Hamiltonians in quantum many-body system of interacting particles (the elliptic Ruijsenaars-Schneider model). Commutativity of operators can be established using several different approaches including the Dunkl-Cherednik operators [12, 9, 27], the quantization by dynamical R-matrices [17], the quantization via non-dynamical R-matrix [23], the quantization through the quantum Lax pairs [10] and the group-theoretical approach [2, 4]. The studies of elliptic Macdonald-Ruijsenaars operators and their generalizations attract much attention. Some recent results can be found in [36, 15].
In this paper we propose anisotropic version for elliptic spin Macdonald-Ruijsenaars operators and prove their commutativity following the original approach of [42]. Namely, our strategy is to deduce the underlying identities and then prove them. Compared to [42] (in what follows we refer to it as the scalar case) the derivation and proof of the identities in our case is much more complicated since the elliptic functions are replaced by GLM R-matrices. In this respect we also use the approach of A. Polishchuk [39], where the elliptic Baxter-Belavin R-matrix [5, 6] was shown to satisfy the associative Yang-Baxter equation [18]. Then the GLM elliptic R-matrix is considered as matrix valued function on elliptic curve, and it turns into a certain function (the Kronecker elliptic function) when M = 1. The proof of commutativity of spin operators uses not only the quantum Yang-Baxter equation (and unitarity condition) since the latter is identically fulfilled in M = 1 case, while the identities remain non-trivial in the scalar case. In this way our results provide non-commutative (matrix) generalization of [42].

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we introduce convenient notations for R-matrix products. Then the quantum Yang-Baxter equation (1.8) together with the property (1.9) are transformed into the statements (2.12) and (2.13) of Lemma 2.1. Next, following ideas from [48] and [30] we derive a set of the matrix valued difference operators Dk (1.14). Examples for N = 2, 3, 4 are given in detail in the subsection 2.3. In Section 3 we begin with recalling the derivation of identities in the scalar case. It is a slightly modified version of the original one [42], which is adopted for R-matrix generalization. The R-matrix identities are deduced in Theorem 3, which is a reformulation of the Theorem 1. It is important to mention that all the functions φ (entering the definition of Dk) can be included into R-matrix normalization (1.11) in the identities (1.16)-(1.18). A few explicit examples are given in the end of the Section. Section 4 is devoted to the proof of Theorem 2, i.e. to the proof of R-matrix identities. We start with identities for k = 1 and prove them using the higher order analogue (4.4) for the associative Yang-Baxter equation (1.13) likewise the elliptic function identity (A.35) is a higher order analogue (in φ-functions) of (A.9). Then we proceed to the case k > 1. Here the proof is by induction in k. Main idea is based on the analysis of poles and quasi-periodic properties. In Section 5 we briefly discuss some limiting cases including the limit to differential operators, trigonometric and classical limits. As a by-product of our results we also propose elliptic generalization for q-deformed Haldane spin chain. In the Appendix A some basic notations and properties of elliptic functions are given including the definition of GLM elliptic R-matrix (A.17). Appendices B, C and D contain proofs of technical statements underlying derivation and proof of the R-matrix identities.

Besides straightforward application of limit Im(τ)→∞ to the elliptic R-matrix (A.17) one could also perform a gauge transformation (depending on the moduli τ) before the limit. Then the result of the limit provides a variety of different answers. sections.heading: Classical limit.
sections.text:
The spin generalization of the elliptic Ruijsenaars-Schneider model was introduced in [28] at the level of Lax equations in classical mechanics. It is an open problem to describe its Poisson and rmatrix structures and their quantizations. At the same time much progress was achieved in studies of the trigonometric models [3, 16, 11]. In this paper we proposed anisotropic version for elliptic spin Macdonald-Ruijsenaars operators. Since the differential operator (5.4) is the Hamiltonian for the model of interacting tops it is natural to guess that the classical model corresponding to difference operators Dk is the integrable model of relativistic interacting tops [52]. This model is described by the Lax equations related to SLNM -bundles over elliptic curve with non-trivial characteristic classes [31]. The quantization of its phase space is given by a mixture of elliptic quantum group and Sklyanin algebra [45]. At the same time the problem of constructing commuting Hamiltonians looks highly nontrivial in that approach. In present paper we avoid these difficulties by straightforward definition of operators. This allowed us to reduce the problem to derivation and proof of the identities.
Let us also mention that in the rational case with the Yang’s rational R-matrix R~12(z) = ~ −1Id + z−1P12 the constructed operators provide quantization of the custom (not anisotropic) quantum spin Ruijsenaars-Schneider model. Therefore, its classical limit is the rational spin Ruijsenaars-Schneider model introduced in [28].
